title: Will anti-Islamic State forces retake Mosul before 1 January 2017?
preds:
Couldnt have gotten this more wrong if I had tried.  
Was optimistic very early on, that ISIS would not stand and fight, despite @scholarandcat sage advice.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/91404.  I knew they were digging in, but thought that was for a certain amount and key leaders would keep leaving  ---->https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/101045.  I wrongly thought the US forces would play a larger role in the liberation -----> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/105631.  And despite @Amir- giving me the gameplan https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/127756, which I did then reduce to 51% on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/130659, it wasnt a matter of days before I was lured back into optimism by what I thought would be some sort of popular uprising by the residents --->https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/139624 which kept getting reinforced ----> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/146998.  @JP pretty much humiliated me with forecast of how it would play out ---->https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/155871, whereby I was convinced isis wouldnt stand and fight, there would be some uprising and that the residents would flee and US would be more heavily involved, @JP gave me the real version and I ignored it.  
I got the number of fighters horribly wrong https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/320003, thinking less than 4000.  As it stands now, seems over 2500 killed and they are still strong in their resolve which I also got wrong.  I kept getting the uprising wrong https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/325505.  I kept getting the number of fighters wrong and their resolve https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/356859, I kept getting the importance of a political will push to the centre of Mosul for a claim of retaking the city wrong, despite @Dima-K  making that clear I was wrong too ----> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/377694.  
Even up to early November I thought there would be a collapse of ISIS and a big push to claim the city is some way, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/377824.  I realised I was toast mid to end November https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/387690.  I put this q in the Brexit category in that I am so biased even now I think they sh/could have taken Mosul in the timeframe but just got the plan very wrong.  So this q has really been a lesson for my forecasting and where I have political will biases over real world complexities even when the odds are high and an ultimate win is inevitable.  The battle for Mosul has made me worried that we could see an ISIS retaking mosul in some period when there are not the 100,000 fighters backed by US and airforce etc..

I failed badly on this question. I thought analysts were overstating the difficulty of retaking Mosul. I thought ISIS statements they would stand their ground were bluffs and they would melt away once the offensive began. Oh well.

Finis
Abbbad admitted yesterday at least 3 more months.
Iraqi forces launch fresh advance against Islamic State inside Mosul
It looks as though this will take at least three more months.

Iraqi forces will resume their push against Islamic State inside Mosul in the coming days, a U.S. battlefield commander said, in a new phase of the two-month-old operation that will see American troops deployed closer to the front line in the city.
I predict Mosul declared LARGELY captured and Cleared on the 18th of Jan.
Vanishingly small chance of this happening. Just the remote chance that some sort of collapse or withdrawal will happen.
Top Forecasters I Follow, last 20 forecasts (TFIF(20)) ~ 3%.

The coalition continues to make progress and US forces are stepping up air assaults on ISIS targets in Mosul. http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/airstrike-kills-20-injures-scores-in-iraq-s-mosul/713870
US forces are increasing embed per Sylvia http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-mosul-idUSKBN14C1RW
As noted below Iraqi Security Forces are in control of approx.  25% of the city.   
Rudaw news reports Iraqi battle plans for a new Golden Division surge surge to take east Mosul "by New Years eve" 
"ERBIL, Kurdistan Region--Iraqi special forces are gearing up for what they call the second phase of the Mosul offensive to retake the city from the extremist group ISIS, commanders told Rudaw.
The commander of the Golden Division, Fazil Barwari, said that he expects to liberate the east side of the city by New Year ’s Eve.
Iraqi troops claim they have retaken at least 40 neighborhoods of Mosul from ISIS since they launched an offensive on October 17, though this figure has been put at 20 by their coalition partners."
"http://rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/25122016"
Valiant effort and while the IFP will not be resolved retake by January 1, should not detract from very real and substantial gains by coalition  and US Forces. 
This effort should be continued and intensified whether Mosul falls by 1-20-17.
Although I'm not sure at what constitutes a "retake". Is it when someone declares it or when every last ISIS fight has been killed or captured?
Mosul US embeds more extensively to help Iraqis retake northern city from Islamic State

Iraq Situation report from Institute for the Study of War reports ISIS is strongest in the northern provinces of Iraq, maintaining attack capabilities (http://www.understandingwar.org/map/iraq-situation-report-december-15-21-2015). 
A number of anti-ISIS forces have deployed to the area however they have been effectively forced back in recent times.
Sad to say it but they are having a very difficult time retaking Mosul.  Some of the reporting has been over-optimistic.
P(X) = .1   very good.  The Iraqi army taking a break at the winter solstice is a novel concept. Makes one wonder about the political will.

Government security forces suspend operations in eastern Mosul until further notice...don't know sourcing:

Unfortunately the advance has  ground to a halt and Iraqi SF are taking significant losses.

Its interesting that the Russian narrative (on RT etc.) is that Mosul and Aleppo are much the same regarding bombing and killing innocent people. Obviously the aim is get the public to believe that if you want to fight terrorists you have to do it by killing and if you kill civilians that is just an unfortunate consequence and if you don't like it tell your own government not to do, because they are playing by the same rules as Russia. If everyone kills then no one can be blamed.
Iraq is unable to treat the huge numbers of people wounded in Mosul

long time ago seem. I compared metrics of  Iraq Army and shia militias in assault on Falujah and Ramadi.
Simple, Mosul is a lot bigger. and the progress made revealed by satellite photo  on 12-7 is, not even close to  making 1-1-2017 plausible.
This Stratfor report seem substantially accurate
"The Iraqi government’s offensive to retake Mosul from the Islamic State has dragged on for two months, slowed by the massive resistance put up by militants holding out in the city’s neighborhoods. Time is not on the Islamic State's side, but Baghdad’s fight to control Mosul will not be easily won. Even so, the situation is growing desperate for the Islamic State in Iraq. The militants are now completely surrounded and cut off from their core leadership in Syria. The combat will likely intensify in Mosul since Islamic State fighters now know there is little hope for victory or escape, and that they are probably facing death or capture."

and satellite images at https://www.stratfor.com/image/mosul-how-urban-battles-turn-bloody

Some while back I wondered what level of casualties a fighting unit can sustain before it becomes unfunctional.  I suppose that depends in part on the culture, training and structure of the unit, so it might be different for jihadi ISIS fighters and conscripted Iraqi army regulars.

P(X)  = .15
We could have some more fun with question if we want to. Like when will this event really occur? 
I'm a bad question former, but we could do months or quarters or something like that. I'm open for suggestions. @kmcochran fancies herself as a question asker. Maybe, we can do better. I'm on record that my low window is six months. I don't know if the <insert force description here>   has the political will to achieve victory. My tentative high bound is twelve months.  Was denken sie

Time is running out on this forecast. After Aleppo surely the forces against Mosul will take extra care to avoid similar carnage. The Iraqi government had pledged to take Mosul before the end of this year, but this looks unlikely. My assumption is that reducing civilian casualties will take priority over a speedy conclusion. It appear that an uprising is not likely, nor is an IS breakout (its easier to hit forces trying to drive in the countryside than it is forces dug in in the city).
Very unlikely, considering the weather, refugees, and pace of progress

Interesting analysis of the battle for the city:
http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-skeptics/the-battle-mosul-doomed-18740

Reducing again (from 10) based on time remaining and slow progress.  Even if ISIS is "front end loading" the battle and is cut off from supplies and reinforcements, they are not going to surrender, and even if they effectively collapse, it will probably take more than 2 weeks to play out.

This Dec. 11 Voice of America article, http://www.voanews.com/a/islamic-state-mosul/3631929.html, provides an update on the battle -- which will reportedly be drawn-out. No change to my probability estimate of zero that ISIS will be totally kicked out of Mosul by Jan. 1.

It looks like this one is going to solve as a Middle Eastern military can't operate at this scale. Not that it had to solve that way.  One of the things I'm looking for is the political will of the parties involved.
Despite the Abadi pledge, there is not the requisite urgency. (-20)
Closing out this Mosul question reducing from 1 to 0% probability. Slightly over two weeks to go on resolution of this GJ O Q.
From things I have read, it seems likely that ISIL have considerable  support  from the good citizens of Mosul.
Rasheed and Evans (2016) Mon Dec 12, state that:
Well, doesn't look good at all.  ISIS is putting up stiff resistance with 2 weeks to go.
Two weeks out and anti-ISIS forces are only in a few neighborhoods. They're out of time.
Progress has been sluggish thus far and IS appear to be entrenched despite reports of heavy casualties.  Urban warfare is challenging and does not make generally make for quick resolution.

Haider al-Abadi still saying ISF could retake Mosul before year's end.  Ash Carter hedging a bit, saying it's possible Mosul could be retaken before Trump is inaugurated.  Unnamed foreign official saying it will take four months based on casualties suffered by ISF.
20 days left and no major progress

For months I kept my prediction well under the consensus average.  When the Government of Iraq actually got its act together enough to begin the operation in October, I bumped it up, but I should have stayed closer to my original estimate, based on both the internal factors that are inhibiting IA and IP progress, and the external analysis of the rate of progress in the current fight.  The battles for Fallujah, Bayji, Manbij, and others point to a very long siege in Mosul.  However, I am keeping this above zero because, in the general randomness, unpredictability, fog, and friction of war, there is a chance for ISIS to make a sudden tactical withdrawal, or a collapse of their chain-of-command inside Mosul.  I keep going back to Tal Abyad as my example on that for an example of a tactical withdrawal.

Aljazeera is making me look prescient: 
As Iraqi forces continue their military operation to take Mosul from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL, also known as ISIS), another equally important battle to save the Mosul Dam, located 60km north of Mosul, is under way.

This Dec. 10 Reuters article, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-idUSKBN13Z0G9?feedName=topNews&feedType=RSS, paints a picture of a very slow process to liberate Mosul ... months. I'm lowering my probability estimate that Mosul will be fully liberated by Jan. 1.
back to my original forecast. Not long left in 2016.

I used to use military budgets as an estimator of capability in the Middle East. This is why it doesn't work:
One problem is that much of this money is wasted. Billions are splurged on flashy gear like jet fighters or submarines that look impressive but may not be appropriate to the kinds of conflicts they are fighting. Such toys are also hard to maintain. And widespread theft and corruption mean that a lot of kit disappears, or is kept in the barracks (which is one reason why IS was able to nab so much in Iraq).

When Iraqi troops launched the offensive to retake Mosul from ISIS in late October, many families in the city were hopeful. After two years living under the militant group's draconian rule, they believed they would be freed in a matter of days.
Visions of liberation soon gave way to a much bloodier reality. Seven weeks into the operation, only a small sliver of the city's eastern neighborhoods has been declared cleared and secured.
A lethal mistake leads to a harrowing ambush in Iraq’s Mosul

I have been waiting to see the appearance of phase lines and operational halts to reform the battle groups and rearm for task specific missions, but what I am seeing instead is repeated use of the same order of battle. this dooms Iraqi forces to repeat errors and D'aesh is going to make them pay every time they cross into different Urban TERRAIN WITH-OUT A NEW MIX OF TROOPS AND WEAPONS. NOW YOU CAN DO THAT IF YOU USE A A LOT OF DIS-PROPORTIONATE RESPONSE TACTICS AND THERMO-BARIC WEAPONS (AS Russians DO - THINK ALEPPO). Just as a fore instance - how long does it take to realize that every dust storm comes with an assault wave? Do they even have phased array ground surveillance Radar? Why take out EVERY Bridge but one to stop vbied's when you can just put drones on the bridges (unless we are short assets in that department). Anyway - is serves us to remember that when the In-ept battle the Incompetent (think Iran/Iraq war) this is what you get.
"...no sector of Mosul can yet be said to have been truly 'liberated.'"

Continuing to inch the likelihood down. With little over three weeks remaining in the year and hard street-to-street combat required even before getting to the more dense western part of Mosul, I can’t see the likelihood of anti IS forces totally “retaking” the city until early next year.

“They still have freedom of movement between Mosul and Tal Afar, but they don't have freedom of movement beyond Tal Afar and into Syria.”
http://www.scout.com/military/warrior/story/1735956-pentagon-war-report-isis-surrounded-in-mosul

The battle for Mosul started in October and there has been good progress. Even though Obama would love to finish this off before he leaves, I do not think he will push for any significant change of strategy in order to attempt it. That would be short term thinking with little payoff and huge risks. So, he will probably allow it to unfold. Progress will probably be slow and steady, and will almost certainly not be until sometime mid Q1. 
From a forecasting point, there may be a point where victory is declared (e.g. they take something that can be seen as "the town center") even though a lot is left to be cleaned up; but even that is unlikely to happen before year-end.

The predictions on this have been all over the map, and my own have covered a good part of it too.  But now it's December and there just doesn't seem to be enough time left for this to happen this year.  They are making progress, but slowly.
"The grueling house-to-house battles are expected to take months and cost hundreds, if not thousands, of lives, but commanders say they are up to the challenge."[1]

Given:

This Dec. 2 Reuters article, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-mosul-exclusive-idUSKBN13R1KJ, gives an update on the Mosul situation. It will mostly likely be a long, drawn-out process. I'm lowering my probability estimate Mosul will be retaken by Jan. 1.
It seems that we could answer "No" to every war deadline question and be correct at least 75% of the time (due to nature of war rather then underestimations on part of GJP).

Ryan and Salim (2016) December 1, state that:

IRBIL, Iraq — The Islamic State has launched 632 vehicle bombs against Iraqi forces since their offensive to reclaim the city of Mosul began six weeks ago, a senior military official said Thursday.
The widespread use of vehicle-borne bombs — at a pace that amounts to 14 per day — has helped make the battle for the militants’ largest stronghold in Iraq particularly treacherous. ¬Local troops are taking significant losses as they face a well-armed adversary in close-range firefights, while civilians bear the brunt of relentless militant shelling (para. 1-2).

"Six weeks after being launched to international fanfare, the Iraqi armed forces’ assault on Mosul has ground to a halt, despite close coalition air support and the presence of US and British special forces. Iraqi forces have managed to retake a third of the city, but appear to have made no progress for two weeks. The troops have been bogged down in close urban warfare hindered by the presence of hundreds of thousands of civilians who have chosen to stay put. Only about a third of the city east of the river Tigris has been taken."
Affirming forecast. Impossible in the next 31 days.

Downgrading to a SuperForecasting prediction of "Probably Not" going to happen by 1 January 2017. The ISIS/ISIL forces are putting up a harder resistance causing the attacking forces to slow down to reduce civilian casualties numbers. I anticipate that the remaining ISIS/ISIL insurgents will end-up being trapped, surrounded resulting in a fight to the deaths of  them and very heavy casualties on the attacking forces.

Back down to a very slim chance.  Unless something major happens to unseat ISIS on the east side of Mosul and/or if Iraqi forces begin to close on the west and south of the city, the city will not likely fall before 1 Jan.  The CJTF-OIR Deputy Commander is saying that it "will take weeks of hard fighting."

The UN said up to 500,000 civilians in the besieged Iraqi city of Mosul were facing a “catastrophic” drinking-water shortage. Food and electricity are scant too. The American-led coalition trying to drive up to 5,000 Islamic State fighters from their main urban stronghold has urged residents to stay at home. Around 40% of the city has been recaptured

COMMENT: Time to lower expectations of a Xmas present.

Regular Iraqi Army is having difficulty mastering the concept of Combined Arms operations OR another way to put it is that Motorized Infantry is either being ill used or simply refusing to dismount. One can understand the reluctance of regular soldiers to dismount from armored vehicles and conduct dis-mounted Urban Clearing operations. This creates two tiers or phases of operations where Field Commanders consider the safety of troops from direct fire over the efficient and seamless combined operation clearing neighborhoods and resulting safety of pursing and exploiting the momentum of an operation. All of these sputtering - stop and start assaults lose momentum, allowing D'eash to regroup and reset ambushes in front of the assault force direction or axis of operations. This is not unlike the problem in Syria in and around Aleppo where rebels  enjoy regular respites when Syrian forces go home for the day. Russian forces are exploiting advantages, but tend to cease Close Air Support and Bombing at night except when they see strategic advantage.

I've been reading all the posts at http://isis.liveuamap.com/en each day, and once a week I trace the frontlines onto a map.  In almost all sections of the city, the frontline is behind where it supposedly was on Nov 8th.
At the extremely slow current pace of fighting, could well extend for more than a couple of months and not finish till June 2017.
Marching towards this not counting. Disciplined fight and no reckless movements means this is a methodical and protracted fight.

Reducing my estimate by 2%. Iraqi forces are stalled.  News media now saying that while Abadi wanted the city liberated by the end of the year, the forces are allowing themselves a maximum of six months to retake the city:
Yes, between the SDF and Turkey, there is little chance Mosul will remain in the hands of ISIS in a year.

al-Abadi still "hopeful" that Mosul will be liberated by the end of the year.
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-mosul-war-iraq-doesnt-have-the-guts-comments-prime-minister-a7445256.html

With a month to go, it appears that my initial optimism was unwarranted.  Today's Military Times http://www.militarytimes.com/articles/iraq-militarys-limits-are-showing-in-the-drawn-out-battle-for-mosul article asserts that 1. There are 6,000 fighters left in Mosul, not much change from two months ago; 2. The military forces are still making their way through cities on the outskirts of Mosul; 3) Iraqi field commanders have expressed alarm that the progress so far has been lopsided, with the special forces doing most of the fighting, but "other military outfits are halted outside the city limits, unable to move forward because of resistance, battle fatigue, inexperience or lack of weaponry suited for urban warfare."  I conclude that, while it is not impossible for the goal to be achieved in four weeks, it is now unlikely.

SO - when iraqi commanders settled on the assault plan for Mosul - they gave themselves 6months....JUST TO TAKE THE EASTERN PART! "We must continue to advance because we suffer fewer casualties than if we hold still and wait for other units to advance in their sectors," said Brig. Gen. Haider Fadhil of the special forces. "We are trying to advance cautiously to minimize casualties, and we are convinced that we will eventually be asked to liberate the western sector of the city when we are done here."
That may be a while yet. The special forces have driven IS militants from about 15 of eastern Mosul's estimated 39 neighborhoods, some of which are no more than a handful of blocks. Their progress to date places them about 3 kilometers (nearly 2 miles) from the Tigris River, which divides the city in half. The 16th Infantry Division met stiff resistance about 10 kilometers (6 miles) north of the city and has had to halt its advance and hold its positions. IS also appears to use its own drones to gather intelligence on troop movements. An example of their information-gathering abilities came Thursday, when fighters accurately hit with several mortar rounds a tent near the airstrip outside the town of Tal Afar, west of Mosul. The attack took place just minutes after the prime minister concluded a meeting there with leaders of the Shiite militias tasked with liberating Tal Afar.

Revising downward. Now that Iraqi forces are operating within Mosul and surrounding areas, it is easier to predict their rate of progress, especially when it comes to street fighting. I read that itâ€™s a hard slog for Iraqi Special Forces, fighting house to house within the city and conventional units have either halted (armor units, ill-suited for city combat), been bogged down, or are being used as flank protection for the Iraqi Special Forces as they advance. The Western part of the city is more densely populated, suggesting once there, progress will be even slower.
News coming out of Mosul indicates slow slog. Passage of time lessens the chances.
It'll take a miracle.  Maybe it will be considered "retaken" if it gets nuked.
I don't expect them to do by the end of the year. However, it could happen early 2017

Seems like some Iraqis went in there clueless ("I can't use my tanks and so many civilians reduce my options further") and that ISIS is being helped by Mosul's internal Sunni militia. Reports of ISIS soldiers shaving their beards and fleeing Mosul indicates that fear is starting to take hold.  Once conditions start to go against armies the tendency is for them to collapse (that's how ISIS took Mosul in the first place) and 65 days is a long time to go for this question.  I recall that the first Iraq war was generally forecast to be a long drawn out battle, but it last mere weeks as Iraqi defenses collapsed.  There is usually a tipping point after which things deteriorate rapidly.  Such a tipping point could easily come in the next two months.

Holding steady. Frontlines are not moving much in the south as Isis is fighting back (http://isis.liveuamap.com/). I expect that if the Iraqi army is to take the city they will have to reach it from the south while Kurdish forces can seal of the north and east. Maybe the strategy is to keep the western edge partially open in the hope that Isis fighters will retreat to fight another day. 60 days left to reach the city and take it, possible but it still seems rather tight.

Eastern Troops have reached within 5.5 mi of Mosul, but are waiting on Iraqi forces moving on the Southern end of Mosul. ISIL will (very certain) loose Mosul, but I still think it will take longer than Jan 1. 2017. This is an update to a previous forecast. After the offensive had started I updated the forecast to 55%, bur I think that was an huge overestimation.

On the other hand, it is on one level in the interest of the attacking forces to sound gloomy--if they succeed faster, everyone will think them brilliant.  On yet another hand, a gloomy forecast may buck up the defenders, who may figure that if they hang on, the other team will quit the field.  An unduly cheery forecast works the other way--it may demoralize the defenders (or not), but if the campaign turns out to be real tough, the attackers will look stupid and irresponsible and whatnot.  It is trickier than one might think to decide when to hang the MISSION ACCOMPLISHED banner.  Coming up a bit until things get clearer, in case they do.

Clips from BBC article:
"An operation to retake the city, capital of the northern Nineveh governorate, has been planned for months, and analysts say it could last for weeks, if not months.
What can be said with certainty is that the liberation of Mosul will be a multi-phased operation.
First the logistical base for the operation must be established at Qayyarah airbase. This is also the collecting point for the Iraqi forces that will liberate Mosul.
The next phase will be a multi-pronged advance on the outskirts of Mosul. This phase will unfold in fits and spurts: one day 10 miles will be gained easily, another day there will be tough fighting at an IS strongpoint or a pause to bring up supplies.
During November and December the main battle will likely begin. But for the Iraqi and coalition forces the issue of civilians will be a tricky factor."

The Iraqi army are making positive statements about progress and are closing in from the south. The kurds are said to be closing in from the north. The US seems to be knocking out some IS positions.  The number of IS fighters in Mosul is said to be estimated at only 2 or 3 thousand. This sounds like a lot of progress and sounds like Mosul could soon be recaptured. But the Iraqi army have disappointed many times, it is in the nature of the culture to exaggerate. Maybe this time they will drive out IS, but maybe the progress is being made in towns that IS has abandoned. I don't see any compelling reason why the Kurds would want to capture Mosul. They would be considered occupiers by the population, which would not be conducive to peace, so unless someone (the US. the Iraqi government) has made the Kurds a great offer to act as mercenaries I don't see them shedding blood for Mosul. 
What IS plans to do is unknown (to me) if they really have only a few fighters in Mosul it might make sense for them to just disappear and leave Mosul. In which case Mosul could be retaken very easily and quickly. Offset against that possibility is the reality of how long it is taking for the Syrian government to capture Aleppo (I am aware that IS is not the group that is defending Aleppo). Maybe the local residents of Mosul are not quite as afraid of the Iraqi government as the residents of Aleppo are afraid of Syrian government, but wars in this part of the world usually involve a lot of retribution.

Eyeballing this question's Consensus Trend, an interesting inverse correlation with Crude Oil is apparent (negligible WTI/Brent difference). With ISIS's dependency on crude trafficking well documented, their fate in Mosul literally rides on the oil premiums fueling their military assets. Assuming this year's Brent uptrend continues— finishing 2016 at ~ $75—and a crude/consensus delta ratio of ~66, we get consensus probability of ~4% (0.4-((75-51)/66). A quarterly standard deviation of ~$5/bbl around the EOY target puts consensus probability as high as 11% at $70, and <= 0% at $80. This provides a compelling framework for high level players, particularly those more capable of influencing oil prices (than military operations).

"According to the United Nations, IS last week captured some 3,000 people trying to escape the fighting south of Mosul. Some are being used as human shields. Some were shot, others blown up, and there are reports that IS burned some alive.

I think we need to consider how the capture of Mosul could play out and which forces could be involved and what each power would gain or lose. Mosul is a big city with a large Shunni population. Capturing Mosul at a cost of many civilian casualties would not be an attractive legacy for Obama, The US will not want to get into the sort of operation that that the Syrian Government, Iran and Russia are involved in in trying to capture Aleppo. I don't think Obama or most Americans would want to see on their TVs the sort of destruction that has happen in Aleppo, being done by US air strikes on Mosul. 
To the north of Mosul are Kurdish Peshmerga forces, to the South are the (Shia) Iraqi government and army, which is unpopular (or hated) by most Sunnis. So even if ISIS is driven out of Mosul the (Sunni) inhabitants are not necessarily going to welcome their "liberation". This would mean likely mean that a post ISIS Mosul would be a de facto (largly) Sunni city occupied by "foreign" (e.g. Shias, Kurds) forces. After 15 years experience I don't think that the old neo-cons idea that "liberated" Iraqis immediately embrace the ideals of western democracy and live in peace and harmony, has many supporters. 
So my conclusion is that for the Kurds, the US (and allies) and the Iraqi government there are more reasons to avoid a blood bath in Mosul than there are reasons to try for a quick victory. 
Why in spite of this I still think there is a chance of Mosul ceasing to be held by ISIS is that non-ISIS Sunnis from within or without Mosul could throw ISIS out. Then the argument might be how Islamic are these Sunnis?

Reducing forecast (-5) on the enthusiastic argument of @RiseToVoteSir ( http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/292538 ) that the Mosul operation will proceed in accordance with the general joint operational planning phases framework, and that the phase which would include the assault of Mosul is not yet operational, and that (I think) weather will prevent this phase from becoming operational within the relevant time period. I'd be silly to not adapt my thinking to a well-considered argument in a situation (such as this) where I have no special insight or access to privileged information. I'm not going anywhere near the forecast of @RiseToVoteSir, however, because I do continue to believe that: a) there is no real "physical" barrier to accomplishment of the mission (only 4421 jihadist fighters), which situation will continue; b) that what will be determinative is a matter of moral commitment to achieve the objective; and c) the local population, including the PMUs, may perceive it to be in their best interest to demonstrate this commitment irrespective of any coalition planning. Mosul is like a block of wood sitting on a table. It's just sitting there, waiting to be knocked over. There is a (psychological) battle bubbling below the surface: Who is in control of the anti-ISIS operations anyway? The coalition or the Iraqi government? The Iraqi government has staked out an objective (before the end of the year), and therefore their future credibility must be, in some way, correlated with the achievement of this objective. I am not as confident as, I perceive @RiseToVoteSir in being, that it is the coalition planning that will determine the outcome. I am of the opinion that the Iraqi's have their own agenda, and that since the taking of Mosul is "as easy as knocking a block of wood off a table," it might be their motivation and commitment that will prevail.

"Based just seven miles from Mosul, General Bahram Arif Yassin leads a force of 3,200 Iraqi-Kurdish Peshmerga soldiers. Last night he said his force was ready to launch a suicidal offensive against the heavily defended city, home to 10,000 heavily armed IS fanatics.
From his vantage point in the mountains, Yassin and his men observe IS activities in the city. This includes the chilling preparations being made to defend it against the onslaught they know will come.
“From here we can watch them and so we know they are ready. They know that we will attack so they are building their defences. They are pouring oil everywhere, which they will set alight.

The problem with this question is that Mosul is more of a political problem than a military one, so it's difficult to know what would constitute "retaking" the city. Mosul has not been under the control of the Iraqi government since the Iraq War. It was governed, more or less, by a multitude of Sunni gangs and organizations, before it was governed by the Islamic State. If Mosul is "retaken" from the Islamic State, many fighters will just fade into the background from whence they came, to re-emerge under a different banner later on. (Others will go to Libya; many already have.) The citizens of Mosul do not want to be under the control of the Iraqi government. An invasion by the Iraqi Army would be a bad idea. The powers that be in the US seem to recognize this, but what are they going to do about it?

The Syrian city of Raqqa will become a part of the Federal Democratic System of Rojava and Northern Syria following its liberation from Daesh terrorists, a representative of the Syrian Kurdish Democratic Union Party (PYD) in Iraqi Kurdistan, Gharib Hassou, said Thursday.
Last week, the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) alliance announced plans to liberate Raqqa from the terrorist group. On Tuesday, the SDF, with assistance from a US-led international coalition, launched an offensive to free the northern part of the Syrian province.
"Since the assault on Raqqa is carried out by the SDF, it makes sense that after its recapture, the city will become a part of the democratic federal system created by us in northern Syria," Hassou told RIA Novosti.
The Syrian government cannot do anything to oppose the city joining the Kurdish federal system, as "the Syrian army failed to do something with the terrorists in Raqqa," Hassou said.
He noted that the Syrian army was not taking part in the offensive to retake Raqqa.
Syrian Kurds announced the creation of a federal region in the country's north – the Federal Democratic System of Rojava and Northern Syria – at a conference in Hasakah province on March 17. The initiative was criticized by the Syrian government.
Since 2013, Raqqa has been held by the terrorist group Daesh, which is outlawed in the United States and Russia. It has served as the group's de facto capital and witnessed countless atrocities.

I disagree with almost everything Lt. Gen. Tom McInerney says, except his confirmation that the U.S. is not currently "spotting and eliminating weapons and fighters in the desert." There's a myopic focus on "territory" and insufficient emphasis on spotting and killing ISIS fighters wherever they are, particularly as they move to and from locations and engagements. There's a big difference between a grandfather and some child going to market with a dozen goats, and a caravan of fifty or so fighters driving modern trucks with heavy machine guns in the back and adorned by black flags. Such ISIS fighters should always be extremely vulnerable after they have identified themselves in an attack and are withdrawing. ISIS fighters should be tagged with drones during an attack, kept under continuous surveillance, and eliminated with air power or drone guided artillery as they disengage. Why is this tactic not being employed?

@Anneinak POSTED A VERY GOOD COMMENT i WANT TO BUILD ON. Let us assume that the quoted number of 10,000 Daesh defenders is correct. Doctrine (Army Infantry School - TRADOC Command) uses certain ratio's for planning operations. One is that the defender has a built in 3-1 advantage, and in an urban environment that is a 5-1 advantage. There's reason therefore to see need for up to 50,000, but lets say that the the Fist to Arm (support troops required to feed and arm each fighter) ratio is not 5 to 1 as is the case for an expeditionary force but only 3-1 because of the home field advantage - then total force required is a 200,000 strong task force. Last summer, Marines and special operations forces collaborated to re-open Al-Taqaddum Air Base to the southeast in Anbar province, Iraq. The base, another remnant from Operation Iraqi Freedom, allowed U.S. troops to move into position near the population center of Ramadi, which had been overtaken by Islamic State fighters. Iraqi troops successfully reclaimed Ramadi in December.
At Al-Taqaddum, more than 300 Marines from the crisis response task force provide security and support while a much smaller element of about two dozen Marines works directly with Iraqi military leaders to provide mentorship and advising.
A spokesman for Marine Corps Central Command, Maj. Brad Avots, confirmed that the Marine Corps force strength at these bases remained steady even as the new outpost opened.
The Marine Corps presence in Iraq also extends beyond conventional forces. Earlier this year, a Marine Corps colonel with Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command took charge of the staff element for Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force-Iraq, marking the first time MARSOC had formed and deployed a full joint special operations task force staff. That task force, which operates out of an undisclosed location in country, oversees special operations troops from every service.

Retaking Ramadi took 7+ months. Iraqi security forces need to secure the area around Ramadi and Hit to increase the buffer zone around Baghdad and this requires a prominent presence and the painstaking task of clearing out remaining pockets of resistance. This will take time. Furthermore, ISIL has recently taken control over a stretch of highway between Tikrit and Kirkuk. This highlights the fact that an offensive on a city as far north as Mosul will require security of supply lines and efforts to minimize gaps that would facilitate ISIL counter-attacks. Mosul is predominately Sunni, and this requires a delicate and patient approach to free a city inhabited by people that are weary of the Shiite militias and the Shia dominated central Iraqi government. Kurdish forces, who are closer to the city might be held back by economic hardships brought on by low oil prices and lower budgeting from the Iraqi central government. I am considering raising my prediction percentage in the near future because the KRG is currently in Washington negotiating a deal to acquire more funds. KRG's Peshmerga is an effective fighting force within a much better striking position to retake Mosul. If they acquire the needed funds (the KRG has not been able to pay Peshmerga fighters since late 2015) they might find the morale and economic strength to take back the 3rd largest city of Iraq. Iraqi government and Shiite militias will have a much harder time making their way north and gaining the trust of the Mosul population. Furthermore, it seems ISIL is shifting focus to other areas, most notably Libya. This could be construed as a sign of weakness on their part, and an effort to metastasize to other areas that are easier for pseudo- want-to-be-governments to maintain control.

Elite Iraqi troops have taken the lead wherever the country's military forces have had success on the battlefield, and they are expected to do the same in the long-delayed campaign to wrest Mosul back from the Islamic State.
The so-called Counter-Terrorism Service (CTS) troops "are the best light infantry the Iraqis have," said Sen. Jack Reed, a Democrat from Rhode Island and the ranking Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said of the CTS troops.
But, the senator added, they risk being worn out by overuse.
The elite forces recently led the way in taking back Ramadi from militants affiliated with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS and earlier spearheaded the offensive to recapture Tikrit when conventional Iraqi troops and Shia militias backed by Iran failed. They held on at the Baiji oil refinery when others fled and recently routed ISIS in fighting near Haditha in western Anbar province, according to U.S. and Iraqi officials.
"They are beginning to prepare for other efforts to retake territory" from ISIS, said Reed, who recently returned from Iraq and meetings with U.S. and Iraqi commanders.
"One of the major objectives is Mosul," he said, but "that's probably months and months away" in the campaign against ISIS.
Joint Chiefs Chairman Marine Gen. Joseph Dunford said the U.S. was looking at ways to speed up the timeline for commencing operations in Mosul. In Paris on Sunday, Dunford told reporters traveling with him that he will soon make recommendations to President Barack Obama on the possible repositioning of U.S. troops in northern Iraq to aid an assault on Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city.
"We're about winning" and "we want to have the Iraqis win," he said.
The repositioning would involve placing U.S. advisors closer to Mosul than the Joint Operations Center in Irbil, capital of the Kurdish autonomous region, according to a Defense Department news release.
"It is fair to say we will have positions -- we already do (in Irbil) -- up in the north that will facilitate supporting Iraqi security forces as they isolate Mosul," Dunford said after meetings with Gen. Pierre de Villiers, chief of France's defense staff.
For the Iraqi Security Forces, the push north from Baiji up the Tigris River valley to Mosul will require more Iraqi troops and more U.S. soldiers to train them for a major operation, Army Col. Steve Warren, a spokesman for Combined Joint Task Force-Operation Inherent Resolve, said in a briefing to the Pentagon from Baghdad last week.
"Hundreds, not thousands" of additional U.S. troops will have to be deployed for the training assignment, he said. "The reason we need new trainers or additional trainers is because that's really the next step in generating the amount of combat power needed to liberate Mosul."
Warren added, "We know we will need more (Iraqi) brigades to be trained, we'll need more troops trained in more specialties" to liberate Mosul, the largest city controlled by ISIS.
It was impossible to know how many ISIS fighters were defending Mosul, but Warren said the estimates run from 5,000 to 10,000. To take back the city, the second largest in Iraq, "We think we're going to need, you know, in the neighborhood of eight trained brigades" of about 3,000 troops each, he said, "but that's adjustable."
In Ramadi, three brigades of Iraqi Security Forces were used but only after the Counter-Terrorism Service troops cleared the way into the city. The troops threw up a pontoon bridge across the Euphrates River after ISIS militants blew the existing bridges. The elite forces then attacked to the city center, using bulldozers to throw up earth berms on either side of the advance to block ISIS suicide truck bombers on their flanks, Warren said.
The Ramadi assault followed a pattern of Iraqi attack -- CTS troops lead the way, conventional ISF forces conduct clearing operations, and Iraqi National Police, and on occasion Sunni tribal fighter, provide continuing security for rebuilding efforts.
When Ramadi was retaken, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said that Mosul also would be retaken in 2016. "We are coming to liberate Mosul, which will be the fatal blow to" ISIS, he said.
In the north, Fuad Hussein, chief of staff of the Kurdish Peshmerga forces, said his troops were ready for the push on Mosul but were awaiting the arrival of the Counter-Terrorism Service and Iraqi Security Forces.
"We had [a] discussion to liberate Mosul last year in March, and now we're in January 2016. So it has been delayed," Hussein told the Kurdish Rudaw news service last week. "The question is why? To be honest it has to do with the Iraqis -- we need a partner."
Hussein praised the professionalism of the elite CTS troops. "That unit has good fighters and are well organized and has a lot of experience," he said, "So we need them to be with us as partners so that we can jointly, with the American help, liberate Mosul."
Since the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003, the CTS, which was created by the U.S., has received the most training and the best equipment from the U.S., which recognized their unique role in the Iraqi national security structure as a relatively independent and non-sectarian fighting force.
To avoid political influence that plagues other units, the Counter-Terrorism Service reports directly to the prime minister, rather than going through the Ministry of Defense and the Ministry of Interior.
In a paper on the elite troops for the Brookings Institution, retired Army Special Operations Col. David Witty, said, "Organizations such as CTS are at the heart of U.S. strategies in the Middle East that aim to develop indigenous capacity to combat insurgents and terrorists."
After ISIS invaded Iraq and took Mosul in 2014, "five of Iraq's 14 Army divisions were rated as ineffective, or had disappeared completely. U.S. advisers rated remaining units as infiltrated with Shia militias and Sunni extremists. At the other extreme, the Counter-Terrorism Service was assessed as the one bright spot of ISF. It was the best military organ," Witty said.
The elite unit "was able to maintain its cohesion and effectiveness, despite experiencing some of the most intensive combat, suffering heavy losses, and continuing to be used as a regular, although elite, ISF unit, rather than in a dedicated counter-terrorism role," Witty said.
In a round table session with reporters earlier this month, Sen. Reed said of the service, "We need to have capable forces fighting alongside them, and that's the goal, and we are trying to train up those forces now."

I think it is unlikely that anti-Islamic forces will retake Mosul by 1 January 2017 for a variety of reasons.  Since taking the city, ISIS has now had over a year to prepare formidable defenses in a city of 2 million people.  Urban warfare is always costly and takes considerable time, so even if an offensive began this spring I think it unlikely it would be over by the end of the year.  ISIS is likely to be a formidable foe against an Iraqi Army that has proven itself highly ineffective.  There are few other players that seem keen on getting involved that may hasten an ISIS defeat in Mosul.  Turkey has not demonstrated any interest in defeating ISIS since its primary concern is the Kurds.  And, the Kurds are preoccupied with defending its interests against Turkey, so they would likely only get involved reluctantly.  Additionally, neither the American people nor the Obama administration has the willingness to invest the ground forces required to defeat and destroy ISIS.  Finally, the wealthy Gulf/Arab countries have done little to date to help defeat ISIS.  With all that in mind, there seems to be little willingness or ability among any of the likely players to rush into re-taking Mosul before the end of the year in what would undoubtedly be a costly and brutal campaign.

The recapture of Ramadi does not indicate an improvement in the capacity of Iraqi ground troops that would be required to retake Mosul. Mosul has been under IS control for longer and IS forces are quite well entrenched in the city. The battle for Tikrit (a city a tenth the size of Mosul) took months in planning and several weeks for anti-IS forces to secure. A failed attempt to retake Mosul could have disastrous effects on the already low morale of the Iraqi army which means they are unlikely to attempt it without a high degree of confidence. In order to attempt it the army would likely need to be able to encircle Mosul to cut off supply lines and be able to dedicate a substantial number of troops implying that the situation elsewhere had stabilized to the extent that it is feasible to divert troops. 
Troops required: The battle of Tikrit involved around 30,000 anti- IS soldiers (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/03/world/middleeast/iraq-tikrit-isis.html?_r=0). Given that the IS presence in Mosul is more established (though arguably weakened by a lack of funds/troop payment), the city is over 10 times as large as Tikrit, it is located deeper in IS territory  making it easier for them to get reinforcements and the central government has been unpopular in the past, Mosul is expected to be a harder fight. As such I am estimating the coalition will not attempt it with less than 60,000 troops.

Pros: Increase in airstrikes in Jan. 2016 could be leading up to an invasion as it has in other places in ISIS-controlled territory and even in the past in Mosul itself. Rumors are that coalition forces are being reassigned to training duties to help train anti-IS forces for an assault on Mosul.
Cons: Most fighting has been in the north western part of ISIS territory. USA continues policy of "containment" in an attempt to let ISIS die on the vine.

Retaking Ramadi took 7+ months. Iraqi security forces need to secure the Ramadi and Hit to increase the buffer zone around Baghdad and this requires a prominent presence and the painstaking task of clearing out remaining pockets of resistance. This will take time. Furthermore, ISIL has recently taken control over a stretch of highway between Tikrit and Kirkuk. This highlights the fact that an offensive on a city as far north as Mosul will require security of supply lines and a minimizing gaps that allow for ISIL counter-attacks. Furthermore, Mosul is predominately Sunni, and this requires a delicate and patient approach to free a city inhabited by people that are weary of the Shiite militias and the Shia dominated central Iraqi government. Kurdish forces, who are closer to the city might be held back by economic hardships brought on by low oil prices and lower payments from the Iraqi central government.  I am considering raising my prediction percentage in the near future because the KDP is currently in Washington negotiating a deal to acquire more funds. KDP's Peshmerga is an effective fighting force within a much better striking position to retake Mosul. If they acquire the needed funds (KDP has not been able to pay Peshmerga fighters since late 2015) they might find the morale and economic strength to take back the 3rd largest city of Iraq. Furthermore, it seems ISIL is shifting focus to other areas, most notably Libya. Added 8% because Sunni troops are being used, some fighting for their homes in Mosul, which gives them a psychological advantage (12%)
Added 15% because airstrikes will likely be part of the offensive (27%)

...the push into Ramadi cannot yet be regarded as decisive. First, it took the Iraqi military seven long months — since May 2015 — to make progress into the central neighborhoods of the city. Since the past summer, with the help of the US Air Force, Baghdad has been repeatedly unable to dislodge IS militants. A state military force deploying the latest weapons, operationally supported by the United States with air cover and, reportedly, ground troops, accompanied by Iran’s top military commanders, US-armed tribesmen and led by vengeful sectarian militias has been haphazardly fighting for more than half a year for a mid-size city 100 kilometers (60 miles) from Baghdad that it should not have lost in the first place and which was seized as an afterthought by a nonstate armed group that had already won the prize in Mosul.
Second, since Ramadi has been declared "liberated," IS has stepped up its urban guerrilla tactics with deadly results for the elite Iraqi troops. Observer tribesmen claim that the group still controls a third of the city, and there are reports of neighborhoods with the IS flag flying within a hundred meters of the national troops. In the midst of a devastated city, we are at best looking at a prolonged tit-for-tat phase of factional advance-and-retreat cycles previously witnessed elsewhere, notably in Fallujah. In truth, the price paid by the Iraqi military and the US forces in Ramadi is already too high. The strategy they worked on for the past months is now known to IS, which wasted no time in switching in situ to suicide-attack mode and withdrew its fighters to "stretch the enemy," keeping them in expectation of a possible counterattack. There are already indications of the Iraqi authorities overplaying their hand with statements that IS will be defeated in 2016 and Mosul is next.
Finally, and most revealingly, Ramadi is arguably not that important for IS. The group will only be dealt a blow in Iraq when the city of Mosul is brought back under the control of the central government. Until then, all engagements are de facto sideshows...

Working against a 2016 recapture of Mosul: The recent retaking of Ramadi by ISF and Peshmerga forces took roughly three months <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ramadi_(2015%E2%80%93present)>, which I will set as a minimum lower bound for the taking of Mosul unless there is a significant increase in international involvement. The actual time it will take to retake Mosul will likely be longer than that required to retake Ramadi, given Mosul's importance and IS investment in retaining (and with more time in control of Mosul, they have more time to reinforce their position). So, the longer a full assault is delayed, the lower the odds of anti-IS forces retaking Mosul in 2016; I should regularly reduce the odds as the year goes by, ceteris parabus. Additionally, Iraqi generals seem to be overly optimistic <http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/06/14/an-iraqi-general-s-plan-to-retake-mosul-is-a-fantasy.html> as do some American officials <http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/liberation-mosul-will-within-months-says-john-allen/>. Let's set a reasonable amount of time for retaking Mosul, after efforts begin in earnest, at a 6 month minimum (see US Army Col Warren's comment <http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-mosul-exclusive-idUSKBN0UC0JP20151229> on patience relative to Ramadi). In order to retake Mosul in 2016, those efforts will have to begin by June. Yet Iraqi forces still need to take Fallujah, where they have stalled <http://www.ibtimes.com/iraqi-forces-capture-ramadi-isis-look-toward-fallujah-mosul-2240563>, after which they will need to regroup before beginning the assault on Mosul. If everything went absolutely perfectly, Mosul might be retaken in December 2016. Perfection is very unlikely, as is the probability of Iraq retaking Mosul before 2017.

On the plus side, the forces in Ramadi are alleged to be excluding the Shiite militias that have caused so much harm with their history of ethnic cleansing of Sunni civilians. However, given the multiethnic nature of Mosul before the arrival of Daesh/ISIS, it may be harder to exclude them.

There are several reasons it is less likely that the Iraqi army will be able to retake Mosul before Jan 1, 2017. 
1. Ramadi is closer to Baghdad and further from Syria and ISIS "heartlands." This means that it would be easier for the Iraqi army to cut supply lines and get its own troops to the area. 
2. Mosul is Sunni. The Iraq army is mostly Shia. The Iraqi defence forces that were supposed to stop ISIS simply threw down their weapons and left when ISIS approached. Similarly, Kurds would not have an easy time taking the city and have no interest in taking areas they can't hold. 
3. Since Pres. Obama is in office through mid-January 2018, even if a hawk is elected to the White House, short of a black swan event, it is unlikely that US or other foreign troops will be in the area to re-take the city. 
4. It took months of preparation and fighting to re-take Ramadi, which had a war-time population of around 70k people. Mosul is much, much larger (600k people). Many of these people may not be fans of ISIS but are even less enchanted by the idea of Americans, Kurds or Sunnis in control.

The date is a year away and increasing pressure is being applied against ISIS. Although the Iraq and Syrian regions are being targeted separated the gradual mobilization of forces including Russia make it increasingly unlikely they will be able to hold on to their gains. Additionally Iraqi victories will create a positive feedback loop.

Islamic State forces are going to find it increasingly difficult to hold territory and stave off forces from the various coalitions acting against them. Ultimately, this will result in them becoming a guerrilla group - per the example of Al Qaeda - rather than a geographically definable entity. Many of their leaders are being taken out during air strikes on existing strongholds, which will cause surviving leaders to take refuge in less obvious target areas. Without the demonstrated organisational abilities of these leaders, maintaining a disciplined frontline in their current strongholds will become impossible against larger conventional forces coming into direct conflict in towns like Mosul.

It is likely to take several months to stabilize Ramadi before a move can be made on Mosul. Mosul appears to be a stronger ISIL position, and overcoming it is likely to take several more months. Barring a significant commitment of ground troops from US or EU, I'm not optimistic.

Overall I am quite pessimistic based on the performance of the Iraqi Army to date.  Many of the other commentators have done a good job of analyzing the difficulties the Iraqi Army will have in rapidly shifting from Ramadi to Mosul to take Mosul by 1 Jan.  After they finish Ramadi, which will take a few months more to consolidate, the IA will then have to lick its wounds and prepare for the next operation.  (and everything will slow down for the summer) While they say that the next operation is Mosul, and the US is certainly pressuring them to go for Mosul, they will have a decision point.  There is one strategic factor about this decision point that I have not seen discussed.  The Baghdad government has no incentive to remove threats against the Kurds.  As soon as the Iraqi Army retakes Mosul, then Barzani and the KRG are safe from the ISIL threat, meaning that they then have fewer constraints on "misbehavior" (from Baghdad's perspective): actions that promote KRG independence, just like they were doing before the fall of Mosul.  So why would Baghdad sacrifice Shia blood to remove a threat to the KRG before they have to? So it seems doubtful that they will put a lot of pressure from the top to make the operation happen quickly.  And to make it happen before 1 Jan 17 would require a lot of command pressure to overcome the Iraqi's army's risk aversion, organizational problems, force generation, overcoming losses, etc.
On the other hand, I bumped my prediction back up from a low around 5-10% to account for the non-zero chance of a rapid ISIL collapse (partial or total).  War is the realm of chance after all.  There are numerous indications of the effects of attrition on ISIL.  There are two possible models for this, a rapid "wild fire" collapse or a slow fight to the end.  Their performance to date would favor the attritional slugfest.  However, the complexity of human institutions in violent conflict leads to unpredictable outcomes.  
Another possibility is an ISIL decision to not contest Mosul, which could lead to an earlier far to the IA.  The precedent for this is Tal Abyad, which ISIL chose to not fight for.  Not fighting for Mosul would be a much more momentous decision, however, so I do not think this is a high probability outcome, just possible.

In testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Max Boot, has provides indicators that must occur in order to affect the outcome of the ongoing conflict with Islamic State.  He has indicated that containment should not be the goal but rather defeat.   With the current engagement in Ramadi (Iraq), retaking Mosul will involve a protracted conflict among various military and insurgent actors.  If their is a military victory in Ramadi, their will undoubtedly be an engagement for Mosul.   However, in Boot's testimony he states that  "To defeat the Islamic State, the United States must step up its bombing campaign, allow U.S. joint tactical air controllers to operate on the battlefield, task Special Operations Forces to directly target Islamic State networks, and provide a force of 20,000 to 30,000 in order to galvanize and support a Sunni [anti-Islamic] uprising in Iraq and Syria. "  While this observatio n might indicate a successful outcome for the war against IS, does it provide is with some analytic insight into what might happen in Mosul? Main factors
1) Status of supply lines. If the anti-IS coalition can continue to restrict flows of fighters and military/civilian supplies into the city they'll both weaken the IS position and reduce local support, or acceptance, of their presence.
2) IS has had significant time to boobytrap, lay IEDs, dig bunkers and trenches, erect roadblocks and position suicide snipers, which will make wresting full control of the city
3) Aligning the forces necessary to take a city the size of Mosul some time. Given it's location and population, Iranian backed militias will likely not be involved, increasing the need for the Kurdish forces. 
4) Thus, the involvement of the YPG,  Peshmerga, KDP, PKK will likely needed to be sorted which will take some time...
5) As will involvement of foreign troops in terms of who (US, UK, France) and how (airstrikes, advisors, operators, etc.)
6) Determining, in advance, how to manage the outflows of civilians who are trapped and who will remain to control the city

Mosul is effectively under siege due to restrictions on movement imposed by coalition air power. Recent IS attempts to break out by attacking surrounding Kurdish positions were unsuccessful, this can be seen as a desperate throw of the dice by IS. Current conditions require IS fighters (who are on the whole relatively poorly trained and ill disciplined) to live in underground conditions, with limited mobility, supplies or communications. The effects on morale will be debilitating, leading to clashes between IS foreign fighters and local fighters.
The Kurdish Peshmerga will hold firm against any breakout attempts and  with coalition support deny IS supply from the North and East. Meanwhile the Iraqi forces will build a coalition with Sunni tribal groups, that will lead to the erosion of IS control in areas to the west and south, cutting the remaining supply routes with Raqaa in Syria. An assault on Mosul in April-June 2016 is likely and IS will crumble within two months.
